description: From Middle English molde (‚Äúmold, cast‚Äù), from Old French modle, mole, from Latin modulus, from Latin modus. Doublet of module and model.

nouns.description: mold (countable and uncountable, plural molds) (American spelling)

entries.meaning: A hollow form or matrix for shaping a fluid or plastic substance.
A frame or model around or on which something is formed or shaped.
Something that is made in or shaped on a mold.
The shape or pattern of a mold.
General shape or form.
examples: the oval mold of her face

entries.meaning: Distinctive character or type.
examples: a leader in the mold of her predecessors

entries.meaning: A fixed or restrictive pattern or form.
examples: His method of scientific investigation broke the mold and led to a new discovery.

entries.meaning: (architecture) A group of moldings.
examples: the arch mold of a porch or doorway;‚ÄÉ the pier mold of a Gothic pier, meaning the whole profile, section, or combination of parts

entries.meaning: (anatomy) A fontanelle.

verbs.description: mold (third-person singular simple present molds, present participle molding, simple past and past participle molded) (American spelling)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To shape in or on a mold; to form into a particular shape; to give shape to.
examples: Your hands shaped me and made me‚ÄØ‚Ä¶ Remember that you molded me like clay.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To guide or determine the growth or development of; influence
examples: It is you who must mold the minds of your students that they may be wise, farsighted, intelligent, profound in their thinking, devoted to their country and government and fruitful in their work. It is you who must sense as the example.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To fit closely by following the contours of.
(transitive) To make a mold of or from (molten metal, for example) before casting.
(transitive) To ornament with moldings.
(intransitive) To be shaped in or as if in a mold.
examples: These shoes gradually molded to my feet.

description: From Middle English mowlde, noun use and alteration of mowled, past participle of mowlen, moulen (‚Äúto grow moldy‚Äù), from Old Norse mygla (compare dialectal Danish mugle), from Proto-Germanic *mugl≈çnƒÖ, diminutive and denominative of *mukiz 'soft substance' (compare Old Norse myki, mykr (‚Äúcow dung‚Äù)), from Proto-Indo-European *mewk- (‚Äúslick, soft‚Äù). More at muck and meek.

nouns.description: mold (countable and uncountable, plural molds) (American spelling)

entries.meaning: A natural substance in the form of a woolly or furry growth of tiny fungi that appears when organic material lies for a long time exposed to (usually warm and moist) air.
A fungus that creates such colored, furry growths.

verbs.description: mold (third-person singular simple present molds, present participle molding, simple past and past participle molded) (American spelling)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To cause to become moldy; to cause mold to grow upon.
(intransitive) To become moldy; to be covered or filled, in whole or in part, with a mold.

entries.meaning: Loose friable soil, rich in humus and fit for planting.
(UK, dialectal, chiefly plural) Earth, ground.

verbs.description: mold (third-person singular simple present molds, present participle molding, simple past and past participle molded) (American spelling)

entries.meaning: To cover with mold or soil.

entries.meaning: (dialectal or obsolete) The top or crown of the head.
